data.title: Alabama's NFL Draft roster to grow this week
data.meta_description: Every player who has been picked from Alabama during the 82 regular NFL drafts.
data.text:
Elsa/Getty Images

Alabama's draft bonanza is expected to roll on this week in the NFL's 83rd annual player selections.

The Crimson Tide should have at least one player (and, more likely, four) selected in the first round. That would set the SEC record of 10 consecutive years producing a first-round draft choice. Alabama is currently tied for the top SEC mark with Florida, which produced at least one first-round player annually from 1983 through 1991. The Tide's streak started in 2009 when the Cincinnati Bengals chose offensive tackle Andre Smith with the sixth selection.

The draft record for one school producing first-round picks is 14 consecutive years by Miami (Fla.) from 1995 through 2008. Alabama and Florida are next on the list.

Alabama also has 11 players considered solid prospects to be drafted when the NFL teams make their selections in seven rounds Thursday through Saturday, with three or so more players thought to be outside possibilities.

The most Alabama players who have been picked in one draft is 10 in 1945 and 2017. The SEC record for the most players selected from one school in one draft is 11 by Mississippi State in 1944.

The Alabama players picked this week will join a lineup of 339 Crimson Tide players who have selected in the regular NFL Draft:

No. 1 pick

Harry Gilmer, quarterback, Redskins, 1948.

Gilmer led the nation in touchdown passes, interceptions (made, not thrown) and punt-return yards and finished fifth twice in the voting for the Heisman Trophy during his career with the Crimson Tide. Alabama's only No. 1 pick went to a team that had all-time great Sammy Baugh at quarterback, and injuries limited Gilmer to one game as a rookie. The former Woodlawn High School star spent eight seasons in the NFL (six with the Redskins and two with the Lions), went to the Pro Bowl twice and was the Lions' head coach for two seasons.

No. 2 picks

Riley Smith, back, Redskins, 1936; Cornelius Bennett, linebacker, Colts, 1987; Chris Samuels, tackle, Redskins, 2000.

Smith was the second player picked in the first NFL Draft, and, in a way, the first drafted player to reach the pros. Jay Berwanger, the first Heisman Trophy winner (before the award was even called that) and the first player picked in the first draft, decided not to play pro football. Smith played in the Redskins' final season in Boston and two more years in Washington.

Stephen B. Morton

No. 3 picks

Marcell Dareus, defensive tackle, Bills, 2011; Trent Richardson, running back, Browns, 2012.

Picked the year before Richardson, Dareus (pictured) still is playing in the NFL while Richardson hasn't played in a regular-season game since 2014. Now with the Jaguars, Dareus has been a Pro Bowler twice and earned All-Pro recognition in 2014.

AP Photo

No. 4 picks

Lowell Tew, fullback, Redskins, 1948; John Hannah, guard, Patriots, 1973; Jon Hand, defensive end, Colts, 1986; Derrick Thomas, linebacker, Chiefs, 1989; Keith McCants, linebacker, Buccaneers, 1990; Amari Cooper, wide receiver, Raiders, 2015.

Hannah and Thomas (pictured) are members of the Pro Football Hall of Fame, taken out of Alabama at No. 4 16 years apart. Other Hall of Famers that entered the NFL as the No. 4 pick are Chris Doleman, Otto Graham, Joe Greene, Bob Griese, Dan Hampton, Jonathan Ogden, Walter Payton, Gale Sayers and Reggie White.

Getty Images

No. 5 picks

Vaughn "Cisco" Mancha, center, Yanks, 1948; E.J. Junior, linebacker, Cardinals, 1981; John Copeland, defensive end, Bengals, 1993.

When the Boston Yanks drafted Mancha, that made three Alabama players picked in the first five selections of the 1948 draft. The Redskins had chosen Harry Gilmer with the No. 1 pick and Lowell Tew at No. 4.

Kelvin Kuo

No. 6 picks

Lee Roy Jordan, linebacker, Cowboys, 1963; Richard Todd, quarterback, Jets, 1976; Barry Kraus, linebacker, Colts, 1979; Eric Curry, defensive end, Buccaneers, 1993; Andre Smith, tackle, Bengals, 2009; Julio Jones, wide receiver, Falcons, 2011.

The sixth pick has been a productive one for NFL teams where Alabama players are concerned. Current Atlanta Falcons wide receiver Julio Jones (pictured) has five Pro Bowl and two All-Pro selections and has more NFL receiving yards than any other Alabama alumnus. Linebacker Lee Roy Jordan was a five-time Pro Bowler and one-time All-Pro who has more interceptions than any other Crimson Tide alumnus. Jordan played 14 NFL seasons, Krauss played 11, Todd played 10 and Curry played seven. Now with the Cardinals, Smith is preparing for his 10th NFL season.

No. 7 pick

Mark Barron, defensive back, Buccaneers, 2012.

No. 8 picks

Bobby Marlow, back, Giants, 1953; Rolando McClain, linebacker, Raiders, 2010.

It doesn't seem possible today that the Canadian Football League could sign players away from the NFL, but that's what happened with Marlow and others in the 1950s. The former Troy High School star skipped the NFL to sign with the CFL's Saskatchewan Roughriders, where he was a two-way star for eight seasons.

No. 9 picks

Butch Avinger, fullback, Steelers, 1951; Wilbur Jackson, running back, 49ers; 1974; Antonio Langham, defensive back, Browns, 1994; Dee Milliner, defensive back, Jets, 2013.

No. 10 pick

Chance Warmack, guard, Titans, 2013.

No. 11 pick

D.J. Fluker, tackle, Chargers, 2013.

When the Chargers chose Fluker, the pick was the third in a row from Alabama in the 2013 draft. The Jets selected Dee Milliner at No. 9 and the Titans took Chance Warmack at No. 10.

AP Photo

No. 12 pick

Joe Namath, quarterback, Cardinals, 1965.

Obviously, Namath never played for the Cardinals, signing instead with the New York Jets when the NFL and AFL were competing for players. Thus, "Broadway Joe" was born and a Pro Football Hall of Fame career started.

No. 13 pick

Joe Kilgrow, back, Dodgers, 1938.

No. 14 picks

Tarzan White, guard, Giants, 1937; Marty Lyons, defensive end, Jets, 1979.

No. 15 pick

Ed Salem, defensive back, Redskins, 1951.

No. 16 picks

Mike Pitts, defensive tackle, Falcons, 1983; Marlon Humphrey, cornerback, Ravens, 2017.

No. 17 picks

Dre Kirkpatrick, defensive back, Bengals, 2012; C.J. Mosley, linebacker, Ravens, 2013; Jonathan Allen, defensive end, Redskins, 2017.

No. 18 picks

Bob Cryder, tackle, Patriots, 1978; Ryan Kelly, center, Colts, 2016.

AP Photo

No. 19 picks

Shaun Alexander, running back, Seahawks, 2000; O.J. Howard, tight end, Buccaneers, 2017.

Alexander is one of four Alabama alumni to have been the NFL's Most Valuable Player. He won the award in 2005 with the Seahawks, when he led the NFL with 1,880 rushing yards and scored a league-record 27 rushing touchdowns. Bart Starr was the MVP in 1966 with the Packers, and Ken Stabler was the MVP in 1974 with the Raiders. Don Hutson won the Joe F. Carr Trophy, the NFL's original MVP Award, in 1941 and 1942 with the Packers. Huston wasn't drafted because he entered the NFL before the first draft in 1936.

No. 20 picks

Dennis Homan, wide receiver, Cowboys, 1968; Dwayne Rudd, linebacker, Vikings, 1997; Kareem Jackson, defensive back, Texans, 2010.

No. 21 picks

Don McNeal, defensive back, Dolphins, 1980; Ha Ha Clinton-Dix, defensive back, Packers, 2014.

AP Photo

No. 23 picks

Charley Holm, back, Redskins, 1939; Ozzie Newsome, tight end, Browns, 1978.

Newsome spent his entire 13-season NFL playing career with the Browns-- and is still with the team. He's the general manager of the Ravens, which the original Browns became in 1996. The former Colbert County High School star has been in the Pro Football Hall of Fame since 1999. Newsome is preparing to conduct his 16th -- and final -- NFL Draft for the the Ravens this week.

No. 24 pick

Butch Wilson, tight end, Colts, 1963.

No. 25 picks

Fred Davis, tackle, Redskins, 1941; Emanuel King, linebacker, Bengals, 1985; James Carpenter, tackle, Seahawks, 2011; Dont'a Hightower, linebacker, Patriots, 2012.

No. 26 picks

Les Kelley, linebacker, Saints, 1967; Fernando Bryant, defensive back, Jaguars, 1999.

Scott Clause

No. 28 picks

Jim Domnanovich, center, Dodgers, 1943; Mark Ingram, running back, Saints, 2011.

Ingram was Alabama's first Heisman Trophy winner in 2009. He's coming off consecutive 1,000-yard rushing seasons for the Saints and his second Pro Bowl invitation.

No. 29 pick

George Teague, defensive back, Packers, 1993.

No. 30 picks

Bobby Wood, tackle, Rams, 1940; Johnny Davis, running back, Buccaneers, 1978.

AP Photo

No. 31 pick

Paul "Bear" Bryant, end, Dodgers, 1936; Reuben Foster, linebacker, 49ers, 2017.

In 10 NFL drafts, the league's Brooklyn franchise selected 10 players from Alabama, starting with Bryant. He never played in the NFL. Instead, Bryant stepped right into coaching and went on to become a college football icon and a Crimson Tide legend.

No. 33 picks

George Hecht, guard, Cardinals, 1943; Mike Fracchia, back, Cardinals, 1963; DeMeco Ryans, linebacker, Texans, 2006; Landon Collins, defensive back, Giants, 2015.

No. 34 picks

Walt Merrill, tackle, Dodgers, 1940; John Wozniak, guard, Steelers, 1948; Cam Robinson, offensive tackle, Jaguars, 2017.

No. 35 picks

Kevin Lee, wide receiver, Patriots, 1994; Courtney Upshaw, linebacker, Ravens, 2012.

No. 36 picks

George Thornton, defensive tackle, Chargers, 1991; T.J. Yeldon, running back, Jaguars, 2015.

No. 39 pick

Larry Roberts, defensive end, 49ers, 1986.

Al Bello/Getty Images

No. 40 picks

Ray Ogden, tight end, Cardinals, 1965; Bob Baumhower, nose tackle, Dolphins, 1977; David Palmer, wide receiver, Vikings, 1994.

Palmer was the first player with 1,000 receiving yards in a season at Alabama, and he finished third in the balloting for the 1993 Heisman Trophy. In seven seasons with the Vikings, Palmer caught 162 passes for 1,610 yards, but he has more punt-return and more kickoff-return yards in the NFL than any other Alabama alumnus.

No. 41 pick

Reggie Ragland, linebacker, Bills, 2016.

No. 42 pick

Cornelius Griffin, defensive tackle, Giants, 2000.

No. 43 picks

Billy Neighbors, guard, Redskins, 1962; Roman Harper, defensive back, Saints, 2006.

No. 44 picks

Kavanaugh Francis, center, Lions, 1936; Cyrus Kouandjio, tackle, Bills, 2014.

Charlie Riedel

No. 45 pick

Derrick Henry, running back, Titans, 2016.

Henry won the Heisman Trophy in 2015 by running for an SEC-record 2,219 yards and 28 touchdowns and joined the Titans as a second-round draft choice -- 17 spots behind where Alabama's first Heisman winner, Mark Ingram, went in the draft in 2011. In two NFL seasons backing up DeMarco Murray, Henry ran for 1,234 yards. With Murray injured, Henry had 156 rushing yards in a playoff victory over the Chiefs on Jan. 6.

No. 46 picks

Sherman Williams, running back, Cowboys, 1995; Justin Smiley, guard, 49ers, 2004; A'Shawn Robinson, defensive tackle, Lions, 2016.

AP Photo

No. 48 picks

Dwight Stephenson, center, Dolphins, 1980; Siran Stacy, running back, Eagles, 1992.

Stephenson didn't become a full-time starter until his third season, and six years later, he suffered a career-ending injury. In between, he was a Pro Bowler five times and a first-team All-Pro four times. He joined the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1998.

No. 49 picks

Jarran Reed, defensive tackle, Seahawks, 2016; Ryan Anderson, outside linebacker, Redskins, 2017.

No. 50 pick

Javier Arenas, defensive back, Chiefs, 2010.

No. 51 pick

Lester Sims, defensive end, Browns, 1972.

AP Photo

No. 52 pick

Ken Stabler, quarterback, Raiders, 1968.

Stabler played for the Spokane Shockers of the Continental Football League before he ever took a snap for the Raiders. But when he replaced Daryle Lamonica as Oakland's quarterback, he was on the way to the Pro Football Hall of Fame, although it took until 2016 for the former Foley High School star to be enshrined.

No. 53 picks

Leroy Monsky, guard, Dodgers, 1938; Mike Washington, defensive back, Colts, 1975.

No. 54 picks

George Mason, tackle, Steelers, 1955; Wayne Wheeler, wide receiver, Bears, 1974; Rod Rutledge, tight end Patriots, 1998.

No. 55 pick

Dalvin Tomlinson, defensive tackle, Giants, 2017.

No. 56 pick

Charley Hannah, guard, Buccaneers, 1977; Tony Dixon, defensive back, Cowboys, 2001.

No. 57 picks

Antwan Odom, defensive end, Titans, 2004; Terrence Cody, defensive tackle, Ravens, 2010.

No. 58 pick

Hal Newman, end, Dodgers, 1941.

No. 60 picks

Jeremy Nunley, defensive end, Oilers, 1994; Cyrus Jones, defensive back, Patriots, 2016.

Tony Avelar

No. 61 picks

Phil Tinsley, end, Cardinals, 1946; Benny Nelson, defensive back, Lions, 1964; Tony Nathan, running back, Dolphins, 1979; Eddie Lacy, running back, Packers, 2013.

Currently a free agent, Lacy ran for 1,178 yards as a rookie and 1,139 yards in his second season for the Packers. In the three years since, he ran for 1,297 yards in 29 games.

No. 62 picks

Johnny Musso, running back, Bears, 1972; Antonio London, linebacker, Lions, 1993.

No. 65 pick

Benny Perrin, defensive back, Cardinals, 1982.

No. 67 pick

Corky Tharp, defensive back, Rams, 1955.

No. 69 picks

Bobby Luna, defensive back, 49ers, 1955; Bill Rice, end, Cardinals, 1962; Steve Wright, tackle, Packers, 1964; Saleem Rasheed, linebacker, 49ers, 2002.

No. 70 picks

Tony Leon, guard, Redskins, 1943; Johnny August, back, Rams, 1945; Jim Cain, defensive end, Cardinals, 1949.

No. 71 pick

Kevin Turner, fullback, Patriots, 1992.

No. 72 pick

Jeremiah Castille, defensive back, Buccaneers, 1983.

No. 73 picks

Lew Bostick, guard, Rams, 1939; Herb Hannah, tackle, Giants, 1951; Bobby Jackson, defensive back, Packers, 1959; Kenyan Drake, running back, Dolphins, 2016.

No. 74 pick

Glen Coffee, running back, 49ers, 2009.

No. 75 pick

Ricky Moore, running back, 49ers, 1985.

No. 77 pick

Antoine Caldwell, guard, Texans, 2009.

No. 78 picks

Mitch Olenski, tackle, Dodgers, 1944; Tim Williams, outside linebacker, Ravens, 2017.

No. 79 picks

Noah Langdale, tackle, Packers, 1942; Evan Mathis, guard, Panthers, 2005; ArDarius Stewart, wide receiver, Packers, 2017.

Langdale was the first of 22 Alabama players who have been drafted by the Packers, tied with the Cardinals and Redskins for the most by one NFL team. He never played in the NFL, but coached at Alabama in 1942, joined the U.S. Navy during World War II, went to law school at Harvard and spent 31 years as the president of Georgia State. (Langdale is No. 38 in the photo.)

No. 81 pick

Kenny Smith, defensive tackle, Saints, 2001.

No. 82 pick

Louis Thompson, defensive tackle, Giants, 1967.

No. 83 pick

Sid Youngleman, defensive tackle, 49ers, 1954.

No. 84 picks

Ray Richeson, guard, Eagles, 1948; Shannon Brown, defensive tackle, Falcons, 1996.

No. 85 pick

Brodie Croyle, quarterback, Chiefs, 2006.

No. 87 pick

Jerry Watford, guard, Cardinals, 1953.

No. 90 pick

Ed Hickerson, guard, Redskins, 1941.

No. 91 pick

Wayne Trimble, defensive back, 49ers, 1967.

No. 92 pick

Jess Richardson, defensive tackle, Eagles, 1953.

No. 93 pick

Cary Cox, center, Steelers, 1940.

No. 94 picks

Larry Lauer, center, Yanks, 1951; Derrick Lassic, running back, Cowboys, 1993.

No. 95 picks

Bill Shipp, tackle, Giants, 1954; Rashad Johnson, defensive back, Cardinals, 2009.

No. 96 pick

Bob Hood, end, Steelers, 1949.

No. 98 pick

Mike Johnson, guard, Falcons, 2010.

No. 99 pick

Nico Johnson, linebacker, Chiefs, 2013.

No. 100 pick

Michael Myers, defensive tackle, Cowboys, 1998.

No. 101 pick

Ed Culpepper, Packers, defensive tackle, 1955.

No. 102 pick

Sam Shade, defensive back, Bengals, 1995.

No. 103 picks

Don Comstock, back, Browns, 1957; Jim Loftin, back, Lions, 1958.

No. 107 pick

Kendrick Burton, defensive end, Oilers, 1996.

No. 108 picks

Wayne Rhodes, defensive back, Bears, 1976; Dameian Jeffries, defensive end, Saints, 1995; Jalston Fowler, fullback, Titans, 2015.

Elsa/Getty Images

No. 109 picks

Joe Carter, running back, Dolphins, 1984; Jarret Johnson, defensive end, Ravens, 2003.

An outside linebacker as well as a defensive end in the NFL, Johnson played in 184 regular-season and 13 playoff games with the Baltimore Ravens and San Diego Chargers.

No. 110 picks

Tommy Lewis, back, Cardinals, 1954; Ray Perkins, wide receiver, Colts, 1966.

No. 112 picks

Arie Kouandjio, guard, Redskins, 2015; Eddie Jackson, safety, Bears.

No. 113 pick

Barrett Jones, guard, Rams, 2013.

No. 114 pick

Rebel Steiner, defensive back, Packers, 1949.

AP Photo

No. 117 picks

Byron Braggs, defensive end, Packers, 1981; Deshea Townsend defensive back, Steelers, 1998.

Townsend played 13 seasons in the NFL -- 12 with the Steelers. The Steelers haven't picked a Crimson Tide player since taking Townsend, the longest draft drought for Alabama among current NFL teams.

No. 120 pick

Frank McClendon, tackle, Vikings, 1965.

No. 121 pick

Steve Mott, center, Lions, 1983.

No. 122 picks

George Weeks, defensive end, Eagles, 1943; Curtis Alexander, running back, Broncos, 1998.

No. 123 picks

John Wyhonic, guard, Eagles, 1942; Kevin Norwood, wide receiver, Seahawks, 2014.

Wyhonic was drafted in 1942. He didn't reach the NFL until 1946. What happened in between? World War II. Wyhonic's military service delayed his entry into pro football for four years, and he played four seasons.

No. 125 picks

Sam Sharp, end, Rams, 1943; Jack Aland, tackle, Rams, 1945.

No. 126 pick

Bill Baughman, center, Packers, 1944.

No. 129 pick

Brad Ford, defensive back, Lions, 1996.

George Rose/Getty Images

No. 131 picks

Gaylon McCollough, center, Cowboys, 1965; Woodrow Lowe, linebacker, Chargers, 1976.

Lowe spent 11 seasons as the starting right outside linebacker for the Chargers after being the seventh player picked by the team during the 1976 NFL Draft.

Pick No. 132

Russ Craft, defensive back, Eagles, 1943.

No. 133 pick

Hal Self, back, Yanks, 1945.

No. 135 pick

Bill Oliver, back, Packers, 1954.

No. 136 picks

Greg Gilbert, linebacker, Bears, 1989; Josh Chapman, nose tackle, Colts, 2012.

Larry French/Getty Images

No. 137 picks

Patrick Hape, tight end, Buccaneers, 1997; Le'Ron McClain, fullback, Ravens, 2007; Jesse Williams, defensive tackle, Seahawks, 2013.

McClain is the most recent fullback to lead an NFL team in rushing with 902 yards for the Baltimore Ravens in 2008. He earned All-Pro recognition for that season, and the next year, McClain earned another Pro Bowl invitation even though he went from 232 rushing attempts to 46, with 180 rushing yards. That's because in 2009, he turned into a blocking back to help Ray Rice run for 1,339 yards.

No. 138 picks

Sandy Sanford, end, Redskins, 1940; Mike Raines, defensive tackle, 49ers, 1974; Willie Shelby, running back, Bengals, 1976.

No. 140 picks

Fred Sington, tackle, 49ers, 1957; Scott Hunter, quarterback, Packers, 1971; Thornton Chandler, tight end, Cowboys, 1986.

No. 141 pick

Kenny King, defensive end, Cardinals, 2003.

No. 142 pick

Freddie Robinson, defensive back, Colts, 1987.

No. 143 pick

Al Lary, end, Yanks, 1951.

No. 144 pick

John Mangum, defensive back, Bears, 1990.

No. 145 picks

Nick Terlizzi, tackle, Giants, 1946; Kindal Moorehead, defensive tackle, Panthers, 2003.

AP Photo

No. 146 picks

Chris Mohr, punter, Buccaneers, 1989; DeQuan Menzie, defensive back, Chiefs, 2012.

Mohr has appeared in more NFL games than any other former Alabama player -- 239. He's one of three Alabama players drafted as a punter, sandwiched between Greg Gantt in 1974 and Bryne Diehl in 1995. No Alabama specialist has been selected earlier in an NFL Draft than Mohr, who spent 15 seasons in the league and ranks No. 8 in career punts.

No. 149 pick

Jason McAddley, wide receiver, Cardinals, 2002.

No. 151 pick

Eddie Versprille, fullback, Browns, 1964.

No. 152 pick

Bud French, back, Cardinals, 1965.

No. 155 pick

Terry Jones, tight end, Ravens, 2002.

No. 156 picks

Steve Sloan, quarterback, Falcons, 1966; Greg Richardson, wide receiver, Vikings, 1987; Shawn Draper, tackle, Dolphins, 2001.

No. 157 pick

Quinton Dial, defensive end, 49ers, 2013.

AP Photo

No. 158 picks

Dick Flowers, tackle, Redskins, 1949; Howard Cross, tight end, Giants, 1989; Charlie Peprah, defensive back, Giants, 2006.

Cross played in 208 NFL games, more than any other Alabama position player. The former New Hope High School star spent 10 seasons as the Giants' starting tight end, earning a Super Bowl ring in 1990.

No. 159 picks

Jim Emmons, tackle, Steelers, 1956; Paul Harris, linebacker, Steelers, 1977; Roosevelt Patterson, guard, Raiders, 1994; Mark Anderson, defensive end, Bears, 2006.

AP Photo

No. 160 picks

Jay Barker, quarterback, Packers, 1995; Ed Stinson, defensive end, Cardinals, 2014.

Stinson was the 22nd Alabama player drafted by the Cardinals, tied with the Packers and Redskins for the most by an NFL team. The Cardinals have picked Alabama players in all three of their locations -- Chicago, St. Louis and Phoenix.

No. 162 pick

Freddie Milons, wide receiver, Eagles, 2002.

No. 163 picks

Wayne Hamilton, linebacker, Chargers, 1980; Brent Sowell, defensive tackle, Dolphins, 1986; Derrick Oden, linebacker, Eagles, 1993.

Frank Victores

No. 164 picks

Wesley Britt, tackle, Chargers, 2005; AJ McCarron, quarterback, Bengals, 2014.

McCarron is the only former Alabama quarterback to start in an NFL victory since Jeff Rutledge did so for the Giants in 1987. McCarron did so in 2015 while filling in for injure regular Andy Dalton with the Bengals. After signing with the Bills as a free agent last month, McCarron will have the opportunity to become the Buffalo starter in 2018.

No. 165 pick

Mike Mizerany, guard, Steelers, 1951.

No. 167 picks

Kerry Goode, running back, Buccaneers, 1988; Vinnie Sunseri, defensive back, Saints, 2014.

No. 169 picks

Buddy Aydelette, tackle, Packers, 1980; Curt Jarvis, nose tackle, Buccaneers, 1987.

No. 170 picks

Holt Rast, end, Bears, 1942; Bobby Tom Jenkins, back, Redskins, 1945.

No. 171 pick

Triandos Luke, wide receiver, Broncos, 2004.

No. 174 picks

Jimmy Nelson, back, Cardinals, 1942; John Mitchell, linebacker, 49ers, 1973; Jesse Bendross, wide receiver, Chargers, 1984.

A pioneer African-American player at Alabama, Mitchell didn't get out of his first training camp with the 49ers, but he's spent 27 years in the NFL as an assistant coach. He's currently the assistant head coach for the Steelers. The former Williamson High School star intended to go to law school at Alabama, but he ended up on Bear Bryant's coaching staff instead.

No. 177 pick

Jeoffrey Pagan, defensive end, Texans, 2014.

No. 178 pick

Anthony Bryant, defensive tackle, Buccaneers, 2005.

No. 180 pick

Billy Jackson, running back, Chiefs, 1981.

No. 181 pick

Jim McWhorter, back, Lions, 1945.

No. 184 picks

Rich Wingo, linebacker, Packers, 1979; Bo Wright, running back, Bills, 1988.

No. 187 pick

Greg Gantt, punter, Jets, 1974.

No. 188 picks

Curtis Lynch, tackle, Packers, 1956; George Bethune, linebacker, Rams, 1989.

No. 194 pick

Phillip Brown, linebacker, Falcons, 1988.

No. 195 picks

Pat O'Sullivan, center, Giants, 1949; Ricky Davis, defensive back, Bengals, 1975.

No. 197 pick

Tony Johnson, tight end, Eagles, 1996.

AP Photo

No. 200 picks

Bart Starr, quarterback, Packers, 1956; Ken Harris, running back, Giants, 1980.

Way down here in the draft, the Packers struck green-and-gold. Starr quarterbacked Green Bay to five NFL championships, earned the NFL MVP Award for the 1966 season, won the MVP Award for the first two Super Bowls and entered the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1977.

No. 202 pick

Waine Bacon, defensive back, Falcons, 2003.

No. 204 pick

Toderick Malone, wide receiver, Saints, 1996.

No. 207 pick

Rebel Steiner, end, Lions, 1948

No. 208 pick

Greg McElroy, quarterback, Jets, 2011.

No. 210 pick

Thomas Boyd, linebacker, Packers, 1987.

No. 211 picks

Tommy Brooker, end, Redskins, 1962; Marquis Johnson, defensive back, Rams, 2010; Michael Williams, tight end, Lions, 2013.

No. 212 pick

Calvin Culliver, running back, Broncos, 1977.

No. 216 picks

Bill Cadenhead, back, Lions, 1947; Tommy Tolleson, wide receiver, Falcons, 1966.

No. 218 pick

Robert Stewart, defensive tackle, Saints, 1992.

No. 219 pick

Ray Abruzzese, back, Colts, 1962.

No. 220 pick

Lemanski Hall, linebacker, Oilers, 1994.

No. 221 pick

Ted Cook, end, Dodgers, 1944.

No. 222 pick

Derrick Pope, linebacker, Dolphins, 2004.

No. 225 pick

Bryne Diehl, punter, Giants, 1995.

No. 226 pick

Steve Bowman, halfback, Giants, 1966.

No. 228 pick

Austin Shepherd, tackle, Vikings, 2015.

No. 229 pick

Wayne Davis, linebacker, Cardinals, 1987.

No. 230 pick

Cecil Dowdy, linebacker, Browns, 1987.

No. 231 pick

Wes Neighbors, center, Oilers, 1987.

No. 235 picks

Ahmaad Galloway, running back, Broncos, 2003; Cornelius Wortham, linebacker, Seahawks, 2005.

No. 236 picks

Dave Brown, wingback, Giants, 1943; Ralph Staten, defensive back, Ravens, 1997.

No. 239 pick

Norm Mosley, tailback, Eagles, 1945.

No. 240 pick

Ed White, end, Redskins, 1950.

No. 243 pick

David Ray, kicker, Browns, 1966.

Ray is the only Alabama player drafted purely as a place-kicker. It took him three years to get on the field, and his first regular assignment as an NFL kicker came in 1970 with the Rams. Ray led the NFL in field goals and points in 1973.

No. 244 pick

Joe Curtis, end, Cardinals, 1953.

No. 246 picks

Warren Lyles, defensive tackle, Chargers, 1982; Kenneth Darby, running back, Buccaneers, 2007.

No. 247 picks

Bob Conway, back, Packers, 1953; Steve Whitman, running back, Chargers, 1980; Brandon Deaderick, defensive end, Patriots, 2010; Brad Smelley, tight end, Browns, 2012.

No. 250 pick

D.J. Gambrell, centers, Rams, 1946.

No. 253 picks

James Mallard, wide receiver, Cardinals, 1981; Chris Goode, defensive back, Colts, 1987; Xzavier Dickson, linebacker, Patriots, 2015.

No. 255 pick

Ramzee Robinson, defensive back, Lions, 2007.

No. 257 pick

Elliott Speed, center, Redskins, 1951.

No. 258 pick

Jack Green, guard, Bears, 1945.

No. 260 pick

Mike Hall, linebacker, Jets, 1969.

No. 266 pick

David Bailey, wide receiver, Packers, 1972.

No. 270 pick

Thomas Rayam, guard, Redskins, 1990.

Matthew Stockman/Getty Images

No. 272 pick

Mark McMillian, defensive back, Eagles, 1992.

Despite standing 5-foot-7, the cornerback had an eight-year career, during which he intercepted 23 passes, which is fourth on the Alabama NFL list. McMillian led the NFL in interception-return yards with 274 for the Chiefs in 1997, when he ran three of his eight picks back for touchdowns.

No. 273 picks

Travis Hunt, tackle, 49ers, 1953; Cecil Ingram, back, Eagles, 1955.

No. 274 pick

Al Sabo, back, Dodgers, 1943.

No. 276 pick

Byron Holdbrooks, defensive tackle, 49ers, 1991.

No. 279 picks

Andy Bires, end, Giants, 1944; Fay Mills, tackle, Redskins, 1946.

No. 282 pick

Jack McKewan, tackle, Bears, 1944.

No. 284 pick

Terry Jones, nose tackle, Packers, 1978.

Jones is the Alabama player taken deepest in the draft who became a regular starter in the NFL. After three seasons as a reserve, he spent three years as a starter for the Packers. He later became a strength-and-conditioning coach for the Crimson Tide. His son can be found on the draft list, too, back at the 155th pick.

No. 290 pick

Leroy Cook, defensive end, Cowboys, 1976.

No. 291 pick

John Smalley, tackle, Packers, 1954.

No. 296 pick

Efrum Thomas, defensive back, Steelers, 1991.

No. 298 pick

Tom Calvin, halfback, Steelers, 1951.

No. 302 pick

Ralph Carrigan, center, Cardinals, 1954.

No. 306 pick

Bobby Wilson, back, Steelers, 1952.

AP Photo

No. 309 picks

Jim Krapf, guard, Raiders, 1973; Robbie Jones, linebacker, Giants, 1983.

Jones is the Alabama player selected deepest in the NFL Draft who played in an NFL regular-season game. He did more than make an appearance, too. The former Demopolis High School standout played four seasons with the New York Giants and was the special-teams captain in 1986, when they won the Super Bowl. (He's pictured above before the Super Bowl with the Giants' linebackers.)

No. 312 pick

Charley Compton, tackle, Rams, 1945.

Al Messerschmidt/Getty Images

No. 313 picks

Major Ogilvie, running back, 49ers, 1981; Mike Shula, quarterback, Buccaneers, 1987.

Shula broke the Alabama single-season record for touchdown passes, but he never played in an NFL regular-season game. After one season with the Bucs, he joined the Tampa Bay coaching staff of Ray Perkins, who'd coached him at Alabama. Shula returned to coach the Crimson Tide from 2003 through 2006. He's now the offensive coordinator of the New York Giants.
